title: Chapter 150
content:
# Chapter 150

Bairan Village sat at a crossroads—close enough to level 100-200 hunting grounds to attract a steady trickle of users, yet too small and too overshadowed by the nearby metropolis of Winston to inspire anyone to call it home. The population hovered around five hundred souls, NPCs and users combined, struggling to grow.

Then Grid married Lady Irene.

The wedding shifted everything. Within a week, the trickle became a flood. Five thousand residents now packed streets that had been dirt paths a month ago. The Tzedakah Guild threw gold at the problem, hiring northern craftsmen and specialists to raise buildings and infrastructure at breakneck speed.

Two travelers stood at the village entrance, mouths slightly open.

"This place has changed." The first user, a swordsman in worn leather, gestured at the skyline. "Last month, there were maybe a dozen hovels. Now look at it."

His companion, a mage, nodded slowly. "Those are proper buildings. Stone foundations, multiple stories..." She trailed off as a crew of workmen hauled timber past them, shouting measurements to each other.

Hundreds of laborers swarmed the construction sites. Hammers rang against nails. Saws bit into fresh wood. The village sprawled outward with each passing hour.

The swordsman whistled. "At this rate, they'll be calling it Bairan City by summer."

"And the security's solid," the mage added. "Tzedakah Guild runs a tight operation."

"Who'd be stupid enough to mess with them anyway?" The swordsman snorted. "Best guild estate I've ever seen. They'll be drowning in tax revenue once this place is finished."

"All because Lady Irene got married." The mage shook her head. "Perfect timing for them."

"Who'd she marry, anyway?"

"Some noble, probably. Does it matter?"

They moved into the crowd. Even with half the users out hunting, two thousand people filled the streets—a chaotic mix of merchants hawking wares, adventurers comparing equipment, and residents going about their daily business.

Then a magician near the central square froze mid-step.

"Wait." She lifted her head, eyes widening. "Do you feel that?"

Her party member, another caster, followed her gaze upward. "Magic power. Massive magic power."

The tallest spire of Bairan Castle pierced the sky at the village's heart. At its peak, energy gathered—a pinprick of light at first, then expanding like a unfurling flower. The air itself seemed to vibrate.

A low-level warrior squinted at the phenomenon. "What is that?"

"Teleportation magic," the first magician breathed. "Mass teleportation."

Someone nearby laughed. "Isn't that third advancement stuff? Man, what kind of event is this?"

"Event! It's gotta be an event!"

"For the National Competition, maybe?"

Excitement rippled through the crowd. Users pointed at the sky, pulling out recording crystals to capture the moment. The magic circle expanded, brilliant white against the afternoon sun, and then—

*Crack.*

Hundreds of light beams erupted from the circle, screaming downward like artillery fire.

Cheers turned to screams.

> [Warning: You are under attack!]

"**Infidels! Receive God Yatan's judgment!**"

The beams struck earth. Where light touched ground, figures emerged—men and women in dark robes, their faces twisted with zealous fury. Black magic poured from their hands before their feet even found purchase.

"**Witness the glory of God Yatan!**"

**BOOM. BOOM. BOOM.**

Explosions tore through the streets. Poison fog billowed outward in noxious clouds, thick and choking. A building the Tzedakah Guild had just finished collapsed, its wooden frame dissolving into black sludge. The flowers lining the merchant's row withered and died in seconds, leaves curling into ash.

Fire erupted from a dozen points at once.

"No—help! Please!"

Blood sprayed across cobblestones as a Yatan believer's blade found an NPC merchant's throat. The man crumpled, gurgling.

The swordsman from earlier drew his weapon with shaking hands. "What the fuck is happening?!"

Over a thousand Yatan followers materialized in Bairan's streets. The weakest among them was level 160. Two hundred wore robes of purple and red—elders, each one cresting level 200 or higher.

Bairan's residents? Average level 140. Half of them were non-combat NPCs.

"Don't engage!" Someone was shouting from the walls. "You'll just die! Fall back!"

But there was nowhere to fall back to.

"**This is divine punishment!**" A red-robed elder raised his staff. Dark lightning crackled at its tip, then lanced forward. It caught three users in mid-retreat, and they screamed as their bodies seized, health bars plummeting.

"Fuck this!" A ranger stabbed at the air, bringing up his menu. "I'm logging out!"

"Me too!"

But the system denied them. Those already engaged in combat found their escape greyed out, unavailable. Others vanished in swirls of light, abandoning the village to its fate.

Less than three hundred users remained to face the horde.

"We're outnumbered!" someone wailed.

"Outnumbered and outleveled!"

The Yatan followers surged forward like a black tide. NPCs fell in droves—shopkeepers, craftsmen, children. Their death cries filled the air, mingling with the crackle of flame and the wet sounds of blades meeting flesh.

Then a roar split the chaos.

"**Someone dares attack MY territory?!**" 

Toon landed in the center of the eastern square with enough force to crack the stones beneath his feet. The head of Bairan's security spat to one side—a habit that made Jishuka grimace every time—and bared his teeth at the invaders.

"Protect the civilians!" He jabbed a finger at the knights and soldiers rallying behind him. "All of you—evacuate the non-combatants! **Now!**"

The guards scattered to their tasks. Toon didn't wait for confirmation. He crossed his arms, wristblades gleaming, and charged alone into a cluster of twenty Yatan believers.

"Get him!"

"**King of the Beasts!**"

His body twisted, bones cracking and reforming. Fur sprouted across expanding muscle. In half a second, where a man had stood, a massive lion prowled—easily twice the size of any natural predator. Its amber eyes locked onto the believers.

They barely had time to scream.

**CRUNCH.**

Toon's paw caved in a believer's ribcage. The man flew backward, limbs flailing, and hit a wall hard enough to leave a crater. He burst into grey light before he hit the ground.

"Kyaaaaack!"

Fangs closed around another cultist's skull. The sickening *pop* echoed across the square.

"Impossible—" A third believer stumbled backward, eyes wide with terror.

Toon pounced. Claws raked across exposed throats. Bodies crumpled like puppets with cut strings.

"**Shackles of Darkness!**"

The purple-robed elders responded, chanting in unison. Black chains materialized from nothingness, wrapping around the great lion's legs, neck, torso. Dozens of them, each one pulsing with cursed energy.

Toon snarled, muscles straining against the bindings. For a moment, he seemed trapped.

Then his form shimmered.

"**Lord of Heaven!**"

The lion compressed, shrinking into the shape of an eagle with obsidian feathers. The shackles, sized for a massive predator, went slack. Toon slipped free and shot into the sky.

"Where—"

He dove. His beak, sharp as any spear, punched through the top of an elder's skull and erupted out the bottom of his jaw.

Even as the elder's body began to dissolve, Toon transformed again—back to the lion, landing with a thunderous **BOOM** that rattled windows.

"**KUWEEEEEOH!**"

The roar was physical force. Sound became weapon. Believers within ten meters clutched their ears, blood streaming from their canals. They dropped to their knees, weaponless, defenseless.

Toon's jaws found their necks one by one.

"Kuhahahaha!" The lion's laughter was disturbingly human. "Fighting is fun! Come on!"

From atop the northern wall, Laella watched the carnage with a mixture of awe and discomfort.

"Mister Toon..." She shook her head, pink hair swaying. "His personality is definitely strange. But those skills..."

She couldn't finish the thought. A group of believers had broken away from the main force, circling toward the soldiers trying to rescue civilians trapped in a burning tavern.

Laella's hand tightened around her orb—the Dark Magic Orb, still humming with power from the Malacus raid. She channeled magic through it, feeling the artifact amplify her strength threefold.

"**Wrath of the Red Witch.**"

The spell erupted from her palm as a column of scarlet energy, wider than a man's torso. It carved a perfectly straight line through the battlefield.

**FWOOOOSH.**

Where it touched, believers ignited. Not mere burns—their bodies turned to ash mid-scream, armor melting, flesh vaporizing. The pillar of magic burned for three full seconds, leaving a scorched trench in the earth.

The soldiers she'd saved gawked up at her.

"Thank you, Miss Laella!"

She nodded, already gathering power for her next cast. *We can't let them overwhelm us. Keep the pressure on.*

At the eastern gate, Vantner skidded to a halt just in time to watch three users fall.

"Pathetic." He spat the word like a curse. The three men—a warrior, a ranger, and a mage—lay crumpled at the feet of a Yatan elder whose black robes were crusted with dried blood.

"**Go to hell,**" the elder intoned, raising his hands for the finishing blow. "**Become God Yatan's eternal servants!**"

"Not today, you bastard."

Vantner's twin axes caught the elder mid-cast. The blades, empowered by the **Genuine Twin Bloody Axes**, bit deep into the man's torso. A hidden mechanism in the weapon shifted—weight redistributing, balance changing—and the second swing came faster than the elder could dodge.

"Keok—!"

The elder split in half vertically, a perfect bisection. Grey light consumed his remains.

The three saved users scrambled to their feet, eyes shining with gratitude and awe.

"Thank you!"

"The number one guardian knight! You saved us!"

"I'm posting this on the forums—Vantner, you're as strong as they say!"

"Hehe..." Vantner scratched his bald head, a grin spreading across his face. After weeks of Grid treating him like a punching bag, the praise felt like cool water in a desert. "It's not such a big deal, really. I just—huh?"

Movement on a rooftop caught his eye. Three stories up, Jishuka stood with her bow drawn, picking off believers with mechanical precision. But behind her, three figures in crimson robes were ascending the building's far side.

*High-ranking believers.* The real threats.

"Shit—"

Vantner moved. His heavy armor slowed him, but not enough to matter. He hit the building's base at a dead run, used a market stall as a springboard, and hauled himself up the wall with pure strength. His fingers found purchase on window ledges, decorative stonework, anything.

He crested the roof just as the lead elder raised a dagger toward Jishuka's unprotected back.

**CLANG.**

Vantner's axe intercepted the blade, deflecting it wide. Jishuka spun, eyebrow raised.

"Took you long enough," she said, a smile playing at her lips.

Her white teeth flashed against her tanned skin. Vantner gave her a thumbs up, planting himself between her and the elders.

"Leave these guys to me!" He brandished both axes. "You just keep killing!"

"Okay~"

*Swish.*

Even after seeing it a hundred times, Vantner couldn't help but be impressed. Jishuka's arrows moved like guided missiles. The first shot traveled a hundred meters, threading between two burning buildings and a panicking crowd to strike a believer who'd been about to execute a family huddled in an alley. The man dropped, an arrow through his eye socket.

Her second shot—a single arrow—struck five mages on a distant rooftop who were chanting a group spell. The shaft pierced the first mage's throat, continued through the second's chest, and skewered the remaining three in a perfect line.

"Basics," Jishuka said, nocking another arrow.

Vantner laughed. "Show-off."

Then the three elders attacked as one.

Across the battlefield, five more high-ranking believers broke from the main force, eyes fixed on the walls where Laella and Zednos continued their magical bombardment.

"Magicians!" one of them hissed. "Kill the magicians!"

They sprinted toward the wall's base, preparing spells to scale it.

None of them heard the footsteps behind them.

"You should always watch your back."

"—?!"

The lead believer's eyes went wide. His hand flew to his throat, but it was already too late. Blood sprayed between his fingers as Faker's dagger withdrew, the blade barely making a sound.

The second elder spun, bringing up a defensive spell, but Faker was already gone—melted into shadow, reappearing behind the third cultist.

"Suddenly—? Keok!"

*Slash.*

Another throat opened. Another body fell.

The remaining three believers formed a defensive triangle, staffs raised, scanning frantically for their invisible assailant. 

"Show yourself, coward!"

Faker's voice came from everywhere and nowhere. "Next."

All three died within the span of two heartbeats—throats slit, major arteries severed. Faker stood amidst their dissolving corpses for only a moment before activating **Stealth** once more, his form blurring into nonexistence.

*The others can handle themselves,* he thought, already seeking his next target.

At the northern gate, a different sort of battle was unfolding.

Ibellin moved through the smoke and chaos with quiet purpose. Unlike Toon's roaring fury or Vantner's blunt aggression, the boy-like swordsman hunted with surgical precision.

He found his targets in a burning mansion—four high-ranking elders cornering six users who'd taken shelter inside.

"This is bullshit!" One of the trapped users, a mage, clutched a bleeding arm. "I just got here! Why do I have to die like this?!"

"All my experience..." A ranger was nearly sobbing. "Months of grinding, gone..."

"Please." A third user, younger than the others, held up trembling hands. "Please, we'll give you anything—"

Ibellin accelerated. His boots hit the mansion's threshold, then a chair, using the momentum to vault over the cowering users and land between them and their executioners.

He drew **Thorn of Deep Grievance** in one smooth motion. The legendary flamberge caught the firelight, its blade writhing like a living thing.

The elders paused.

"You? Alone?" One of them actually laughed.

Ibellin met his gaze. "Overgeared No.2."

It was the nickname Vantner had given him—mockingly at first, but Ibellin had come to wear it with pride. If being 'overgeared' meant relying on powerful items, then so be it. He'd earned this weapon.

*Shing.*

The flamberge moved. Its wave-like edge made the trajectory impossible to predict—what looked like a horizontal slash curved upward at the last instant, opening a gash along an elder's jaw.

"Tch." The elder jumped back, hand going to the wound. "Barely a scratch—heok?"

Blood fountained from the cut. Not a trickle, not a steady flow, but a pressurized spray that painted the floor crimson.

"A magic sword!" another elder shouted, retreating.

"Not quite." Ibellin advanced, his pretty features expressionless. "Just cursed."

He struck again. **Thorn of Deep Grievance** sang through the air, its irregular shape creating impossible angles of attack. One elder tried to parry and found his guard irrelevant—the blade twisted around his staff and opened his forearm to the bone.

*Puk. Slash.*

Blood erupted like a fountain. The elder screamed, dropping his weapon to clutch the wound. Ibellin's return stroke took his head.

The remaining three believers scrambled backward, terror replacing confidence. They threw spells without aiming, desperate to create distance.

Ibellin walked through the magic as if it were rain. Minor burns, shallow cuts—nothing that would stop him. The flamberge rose and fell with metronomic consistency.

*Slash. Stab. Slash.*

Screams echoed through the burning mansion. When silence finally fell, six users stared at the blood-soaked boy who'd saved them.

Ibellin wiped his blade clean on a fallen elder's robe and sheathed it without a word.

"Let's go," he said quietly. "This isn't over yet."

---

The battle for Bairan had only just begun.
